urn:contentItem:5RS8-5DV1-F0J6-J543-00000-00Inspiring young women awarded International Women's Day scholarships2018-03-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisInspiring young women awarded International Women's Day scholarships

Five young women from across the Bega Valley have been awarded International Women's Day scholarships from the Bega Valley Shire Council.

The scholarships were awarded to support their work with the community and to enable them to achieve their goals and aspirations.

Brianna Larkham and Gab Green from Merimbula, Indigo Walker and Leesa Chen from Bega and Eliza Bell from Wolumla were awarded the $500 scholarships acknowledging their contributions to the community and their future plans.

Founder of Topsy-turvy Intimates, Indigo Walker, has been designing and manufacturing underwear for women that celebrates a range of body shapes and the diversity of women within the community.

Ms Walker said that although making underwear may appear as though she is "not doing anything meaningful for the world", she hopes to empower women through her work, particularly those women who do not fit traditional notions of female attractiveness.

"I was seeing women who did not feel attractive and women that weren't being represented and I wanted to bring them to the forefront."

With the scholarship money, Ms Walker hopes to run a half-day underwear making workshop so other women can also learn how to be creative with their underwear.

"The scholarships means that I have a certain aspect of financial security but also the ability to expand and try different designs."

Boilermaker and forest fire fighter Brianna Larkham was inspired to apply for the scholarship to highlight gender equality.

"I wanted to apply so that I could inspire other local young people to pursue whatever career they want, they don't have to stick to gender norms. There are opportunities out there and no need to be stereotyped, you just have to apply and commit yourself," she said.

The 23-year-old of Pambula began her boiler making trade aged-21. She discontinued her studies in Architecture to "try some thing more hands on", she said.

"I really like it! I have helped build massive dehydrators as well as structural fabrications, like beams for houses and construction sites."

"There is a lot of sexism in the area although I think there are a lot of employers and a lot of people out there that are willing to employ women and give them a go," Ms Larkham said.

After completing her apprenticeship she now has her sights set on becoming a Paramedic, using the scholarship to fund her travel expenses for practical work in Queensland as well as textbooks.

urn:contentItem:5V7Y-WGM1-F0JP-W079-00000-00Community input makes Noojee safer2019-01-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisLIFESTYLEPg. 24Community input makes Noojee saferBy CAMILLE SMITH

FIRE AWARENESS 2019 THE Gippsland community of Noojee is at extreme risk of bushfire - deep in a valley, forest uphill in most directions and just three roads out of town.

But the residents are well prepared thanks to huge effort by the local CFA brigade.

"The CFA and DELWP are constantly managing the forest," said resident Wendy Morriss. "It makes me feel confident. We are a community that sees the CFA as the most important organisation in town." Noojee CFA's community engagement plan is an excellent blueprint. It includes education in schools, a community bushfire exercise once every five years, individual property assessments for landowners, an annual All Emergencies All Communities day and ongoing awareness campaigns aimed at visitors.

Community safety co-ordinator and first lieutenant Ken Hitchcock developed the plan, which runs to 2022, and about 15 active CFA volunteer members work tirelessly to deliver it.

Mr Hitchcock organised the All Emergencies All Communities event, which brought together the CFA, SES, Victoria Police, Ambulance Victoria, Forest Fire Management, Baw Baw Shire, Parks Victoria, Vic Forests and the local Lion's Club on November 4 to help people with their pre-fire season planning.

"The CFA expects each brigade to have an open day," Mr Hitchcock said. "I just thought it would be easier to have it as a one-stop shop, so the community could come and ask questions and get answers from the right people." He said the other important event in the plan was the Community Bushfire Exercise, which evolved out of a community fire drill held in 2011 in the aftermath of Black Saturday.

The all-day workshop teaches people about fire behaviour, the local risk and developing fire plans and was most recently held in 2015. The next is scheduled for 2020.

Much of the community plan is informed by the shortcomings of Black Saturday, when Noojee did not burn, but the Bunyip Fire roared dangerously close.

"During Black Saturday I decided to defend my home, but I would never do it again," said Mr Hitchcock, who moved to the area about 15 years ago and joined the Noojee Brigade soon after.

His fire plan had been to evacuate his children to a safer property at Neerim North. But it was not safe enough. By 5pm on Black Saturday that property was under ember attack.

"They were at the top of a hill, surrounded by farmland. I thought they would be better - and they weren't," he said.

"Next time I would evacuate my family far beyond where I did last time. I would make sure they were safe, all the way at Southgate, and I would carry out my CFA duties.

"The Noojee property will have to be left to chance." His advice to others is to take part in all the free education services the CFA provides, be ready to leave early and have insurance.

Resident Wendy is acutely aware a future blaze is not an "if" scenario, but a "when".

"Noojee has not burned since 1939," she said. "If there is any fire burning in Victoria, I keep tabs, especially when it is hot and windy. If it was a certain distance, or if I lost contact, I'd pack up and go."Also if it was a 43C day and windy - fire or no fire - I would leave."

urn:contentItem:5R03-40B1-JD34-V0YH-00000-00Fire publication established in Warracknabeal loses funding2017-11-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisFire publication established in Warracknabeal loses fundingCarly Werner

WIMMERA volunteers are crushed a statewide fire publication established in Warracknabeal has lost funding.

The Country Fire Authority has withdrawn its annual grant for the Fire Wise magazine, which Captain Norm Tosh formed in the Wimmera town in 1947.

Fire Wise - formerly The Fireman - is Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria's official monthly publication.

The group's Horsham-based state councillor Maurice Dumesny said the authority provided thousands of dollars each year - which equated to about $1 for each volunteer statewide - for the publication.

He said Fire Wise was critical for supplying information to volunteers across the state.

"It has been and still is today a great asset to the group," he said.

"It is a way of informing volunteers of brigade news and events, championship results, members service awards, the passing of authority members, and reports on brigade functions raising money for equipment.

"Fire Wise has published stories from Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria, Emergency Management Victoria, the CFA, and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

"My opinion has nothing to do with money but more about trying to stop Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria from having a voice."

In a statement on the Fire Wise website, editor Gordon King said the authority had supported the publication for about 50 years.

He said the funding kept publication costs to a minimum, and helped ensure a free copy of the magazine was available for every brigade captain and group officer each month.

Mr King said while the news was bitterly disappointing, readers should not despair.

"I am determined to make Fire Wise even stronger, more financially secure and even more widely distributed," he said.

"Like the generations who managed The Fireman before me, I am more convinced than ever that it is vitally important for there to be a thriving and respected opportunity for the voice of authority volunteers to be shared, and for the unconstrained conversations about volunteer issues, ideas and opinions to be on the table.

"I know we have many supporters who understand the value and need for a publication such as Fire Wise and I will be working with these people to ensure our ongoing success."

Mr King said the first step was making Fire Wise free online at www.fire-wise.com.au to increase the publication's reach.

urn:contentItem:5PX5-HBY1-F0JP-W070-00000-00Snow one week, scorcher the next2017-11-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Snow one week, scorcher the nextALEX LUTTRELL and HELEN KEMPTON

SOME seriously hot weather is expected to hit the state this weekend and hang around well into next week.

In Hobart, temperatures will reach 22C on Saturday, 24C on Sunday, 27C on Monday, 30C on Tuesday and 29C on Wednesday.

Bureau of Meteorology forecaster Rachel McInerney said a high pressure system would dominate the state next week, with warm air travelling down from the mainland.

"It's a northeast flow [at first] then northerly on Monday, bringing that warm air from the mainland," she said.

Ms McInerney added that Wednesday could bring the cool change, with showers developing.

"We're uncertain of that change with a cooler front crossing." Just last week snow fell on Mt Wellington and two weeks ago Hobart reached 30C, but Ms McInerney said fluctuation wasn't unusual.

"It's the nature of spring, so it could always go back to cold. "It can fluctuate wildly in Tasmania." The outlook comes as the Climate Council of Australia's latest report warned Tasmania would face more severe bushfires and flooding events as a result of intensifying climate change.

It also warned the next three years would be critical if the state were to limit the impact of reduced rainfall, and loss of biodiversity, on our native wildlife.

The influence of climate change on bushfires is measured through increases in the Forest Fire Danger Index, which estimates the conditions suitable for dangerous fires, including high temperatures, low humidity, high winds and preceding dry conditions.

The FFDI has increased, particularly in the populous South and East of the state, the report said. Tasmania's East Coast is already experiencing record dry conditions with the lowest rainfall ever recorded between June and October.

The TFS has already battled one large bushfire this season with a blaze near St Helens taking more than a week to bring under control.

But it is not all doom and gloom with the report championing the emergence of state and local governments as climate leaders.

The report shows 92 per cent of energy used in Tasmania comes from renewable sources and our solar and wind sectors are growing.The CCA said local councils were also taking the issue of climate change seriously.

urn:contentItem:5XHY-T211-JD34-V0Y4-00000-00Parts of Horsham, Northern Grampians and West Wimmera enter into Fire Danger Period2019-11-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisParts of Horsham, Northern Grampians and West Wimmera enter into Fire Danger PeriodJade Bate

FIRE restrictions are now in force for the Horsham, West Wimmera and Northern Grampians municipalities.

Horsham (North), West Wimmera (Central East and Central West), and Northern Grampians entered into the fire danger period on Monday.

Yarriambiack (North) entered into the Fire Danger Period on October 14, while restrictions for West Wimmera (Northern), Hindmarsh and Yarriambiack (Cental) started on November 11.

Fire restrictions have not started for Horsham (South) and West Wimmera (South).

Country Fire Authority District 17 operations manager Craig Brittain said there was an abundance in roadside fuel growth due to good rainfall during winter.

"As fuel loads quickly dry out with the warmer weather and strong winds, the risk of fire is increasing," he said.

"It is incumbent on all members of our communities to ensure we undertake preparation to limit the risk of fires starting, limit the chance of fires taking hold and limit the spread of fires.

"Whilst we know crops and grasses are drying out, bushland is already dry and susceptible to fires, which is a concern.

"While the CFA and its partner agencies Parks Victoria, Forest Fire Management, and Emergency Management Victoria are doing everything we can to prepare for the bushfire season, we look to the community to use common sense and take responsibility for preventing fires."

RELATED: Wimmera residents urged to start preparations early for 2019-20 fire season

Mr Brittain said there was still a short window of opportunity to clean up around properties.

"People need to be aware that if using fire to clean up around their properties they need to register these on 1800 668 511. So far this year, out-of-control burn-offs and unregistered burn-offs have already caused unnecessary call-outs to for brigades," Mr Brittain said.

"You should not burn off when winds are high or high winds are forecast - not only on the day of your burn but for the days afterwards. For information about burn-off restrictions specific to your area, consult your local council."

He said once the Fire Danger Period came into effect, the CFA had a zero-tolerance approach to any fires that had started from negligent behaviour.

"Expect any fire you start to be fully investigated by CFA and Victoria Police," he said.

Last month the CFA issued a haystack fire warning to growers after a spate of haystack fires last season.

CFA District 17 commander Lindsay Barry said haystack fires were always a major concern for the CFA.

"There was a significant increase in haystack fires last year, from stand alone bales to huge piles of bales worth thousands of dollars," he said.

Mr Barry said high rainfalls earlier in the year meant there was more growth in paddocks.

"The amount of hay that is being cut will of course make a big impact on how many haystack fires we have. It's looking like there will be less hay cut this year," he said.

CFA crews attended 83 haystack fires last season across the state, with many occurring in western Victoria. Since 2008, the CFA has responded to more than 1500 haystack fires.

About the Fire Danger Period: THE CFA does issue permits for certain situations during the FDP. However, there are very strict conditions attached to these permits and the liability sits with the permit holder to ensure they always act safely.

During the Fire Danger Period, fires cannot be lit in the open air without a written permit from CFA or a Municipal Fire Prevention Officer.

A written permit is required to burn off grass, undergrowth, weeds or other vegetation during the Fire Danger Period. This permit may be issued by the Municipal Fire Prevention Officer or the CFA District Office.

Lighting a fire in the open without a permit is an offence and can bring a penalty of over $19,000 and/or 12 months imprisonment. Barbecues and fires for cooking and warmth do not require a permit, but must be lit in properly constructed fireplaces.

The use of an incinerator, chainsaw/lawn mower, welding/grinding equipment and vehicles that come in contact with vegetation and machinery with an internal combustion/heat engine are permitted provided conditions are followed.

Mr Brittain said more information on the Fire Danger Period was available on the CFA's website.

While you're with us, you can now receive updates straight to your inbox twice weekly from the Wimmera Mail-Times. To make sure you're up-to-date with all the news from across the Wimmera, sign up below.

urn:contentItem:5XJ5-5VK1-F0JP-W0CV-00000-00Letters to the Editor2019-11-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisCOMMENTARYPg. 13Letters to the Editor

TALKING POINT: Power, bushfires, emissions and climate change In response to the devastating nature of the 2019 bushfires Chris Kenny demands that "facts and science must prevail" ("Climate crusaders exploit fires to push their alarmist view", 16-17/11). The facts are that the World Meteorological Organisation has stated that the 20 warmest years on record have been in the past 22 years, with the degree of warming during the past four years being particularly exceptional.

The facts are that increasing temperatures have seen a consistent increase in the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index, as forecast in 2009 by Professor Ross Bradstock at the Centre for Environmental Risk Management of Bushfires at the University of Wollongong. This risk was supported by the Bureau of Meteorology and the CSIRO in last year's State of the Climate report. The unprecedented fire behaviour we are experiencing was called out by the collective brains trust of many of the nation's former emergency services chiefs in April.

The facts are, Australia negotiated one of the lowest greenhouse reduction targets of any first world nation under the Paris Agreement. Yet under the Coalition government we have had emissions increases for the past four years.

T. Daly, Kingsford, NSW

I am 86. I have a degree in science and forestry, worked in forestry for nearly 40 years, experienced the 1967 southern Tasmanian bushfires in which 62 people died and other big fires in wet rainforests in North West Tasmania. In my book, Chris Kenny's analysis of bushfires in Australia was spot on. It ought to be compulsory reading in every high school in Australia.

Bert Witte, Kingston, Tas

Southeast Australia is yet again threatened with blackouts this summer, further demonstrating that renewables should never have been given carte blanche to exploit the grid without any responsibility for reliability or storage ("Blackouts risk to force states' hand on coal", 19/11).

The irresponsibility of governments of establishing energy policy on virtue signalling rather than proper engineering/economic analysis is showing itself in the form of unaffordable electricity prices, unreliability of supply and ugly environmental repercussions. Quite the opposite of what is required to address drought mitigation, the growing power needs of urban centres and the challenges of climate change adaptation.

Ron Hobba, Camberwell, Vic

In a bid to ensure reliability, Energy Minister Angus Taylor is demanding the states source more power from coal, gas and hydro. Good luck with Victoria. Hazelwood coal-fired power station, which provided a quarter of the state's electricity, was shut down, the future of Yallourn is under a cloud, there is a ban on gas exploration and a 50 per cent renewable energy target by 2030. In 2018, the last coal plant in South Australia was blown up and in NSW Liddell is destined for the scrapheap by 2023.

Taylor was touted as the nation's great hope for keeping the lights on. Unless he does more than reading the riot act to the states, blackouts and high power prices will continue.

Dale Ellis, Innisfail, Qld

We hear again today of more coal-fired generating capacity being closed down years ahead of its use-by date. No doubt the catastrophists will see this as a victory. Don't they read the facts? Coal (and to a lesser extent gas) generators need to keep their turbines spinning 24 hours a day to be prepared for the next drop in wind speed or cloud that obscures the sun. They get paid only for the periods they are required to despatch power into the system to provide backup for unreliable renewables. They get paid little or nothing for being on stand by, yet need to consume huge amounts of fuel to do so. With the table so stacked against them, it's a wonder any are still in business.

K. MacDermott, Binalong, NSW

Australia is the most climate-vulnerable wealthy nation and our per capita emissions are among the highest in the world. While we cannot prevent climate disruption alone, it is in our interests to lead by example in emission abatement.

Jonathan Miller, Curtin, ACT

I find it noteworthy that on Australia Talks on the ABC on Monday night it was claimed that 83 per cent of Australians believe we should take action on climate change yet I do not know anybody who does?F.W. (Bill) Pike, Abernethy, NSW

urn:contentItem:5XJ5-S911-F0J6-J00J-00000-00Parts of Horsham, Northern Grampians and West Wimmera enter into Fire Danger Period2019-11-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Parts of Horsham, Northern Grampians and West Wimmera enter into Fire Danger PeriodJade Bate

FIRE restrictions are now in force for the Horsham, West Wimmera and Northern Grampians municipalities.

Horsham (North), West Wimmera (Central East and Central West), and Northern Grampians entered into the fire danger period on Monday.

Yarriambiack (North) entered into the Fire Danger Period on October 14, while restrictions for West Wimmera (Northern), Hindmarsh and Yarriambiack (Cental) started on November 11.

Fire restrictions have not started for Horsham (South) and West Wimmera (South).

Country Fire Authority District 17 operations manager Craig Brittain said there was an abundance in roadside fuel growth due to good rainfall during winter.

"As fuel loads quickly dry out with the warmer weather and strong winds, the risk of fire is increasing," he said.

"It is incumbent on all members of our communities to ensure we undertake preparation to limit the risk of fires starting, limit the chance of fires taking hold and limit the spread of fires.

"Whilst we know crops and grasses are drying out, bushland is already dry and susceptible to fires, which is a concern.

"While the CFA and its partner agencies Parks Victoria, Forest Fire Management, and Emergency Management Victoria are doing everything we can to prepare for the bushfire season, we look to the community to use common sense and take responsibility for preventing fires."

RELATED: Wimmera residents urged to start preparations early for 2019-20 fire season

Mr Brittain said there was still a short window of opportunity to clean up around properties.

"People need to be aware that if using fire to clean up around their properties they need to register these on 1800 668 511. So far this year, out-of-control burn-offs and unregistered burn-offs have already caused unnecessary call-outs to for brigades," Mr Brittain said.

"You should not burn off when winds are high or high winds are forecast - not only on the day of your burn but for the days afterwards. For information about burn-off restrictions specific to your area, consult your local council."

He said once the Fire Danger Period came into effect, the CFA had a zero-tolerance approach to any fires that had started from negligent behaviour.

"Expect any fire you start to be fully investigated by CFA and Victoria Police," he said.

Last month the CFA issued a haystack fire warning to growers after a spate of haystack fires last season.

CFA District 17 commander Lindsay Barry said haystack fires were always a major concern for the CFA.

"There was a significant increase in haystack fires last year, from stand alone bales to huge piles of bales worth thousands of dollars," he said.

Mr Barry said high rainfalls earlier in the year meant there was more growth in paddocks.

"The amount of hay that is being cut will of course make a big impact on how many haystack fires we have. It's looking like there will be less hay cut this year," he said.

CFA crews attended 83 haystack fires last season across the state, with many occurring in western Victoria. Since 2008, the CFA has responded to more than 1500 haystack fires.

About the Fire Danger Period: THE CFA does issue permits for certain situations during the FDP. However, there are very strict conditions attached to these permits and the liability sits with the permit holder to ensure they always act safely.

During the Fire Danger Period, fires cannot be lit in the open air without a written permit from CFA or a Municipal Fire Prevention Officer.

A written permit is required to burn off grass, undergrowth, weeds or other vegetation during the Fire Danger Period. This permit may be issued by the Municipal Fire Prevention Officer or the CFA District Office.

Lighting a fire in the open without a permit is an offence and can bring a penalty of over $19,000 and/or 12 months imprisonment. Barbecues and fires for cooking and warmth do not require a permit, but must be lit in properly constructed fireplaces.

The use of an incinerator, chainsaw/lawn mower, welding/grinding equipment and vehicles that come in contact with vegetation and machinery with an internal combustion/heat engine are permitted provided conditions are followed.

Mr Brittain said more information on the Fire Danger Period was available on the CFA's website.

While you're with us, you can now receive updates straight to your inbox twice weekly from the Wimmera Mail-Times. To make sure you're up-to-date with all the news from across the Wimmera, sign up below.

urn:contentItem:5GRC-YGT1-F0J6-J2C8-00000-00PMI shows manufacturing slumps to six-year low2015-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13PMI shows manufacturing slumps to six-year low

China's giant manufacturing sector has fallen to a 77-month low, a contraction that will further alarm global markets already nervous about slowing growth in the world's second biggest economy.

The Flash Caixin Purchasing Managers Index for August fell to 47.1, down from July's final reading of 47.8, then the worst outcome in 44 months.

"The PMI for August has fallen further from July's two-year low, indicating that the economy is still in the process of bottoming out," said He Fan, chief economist at Caixin Insight Group.

The August reading showed a worsening in all the major indicators including new orders from domestic and foreign buyers. Analysts had been expecting a pick-up in the PMI from July's surprising weak reading.

A reading below 50 indicates the sector is operating below its long run average. The data is compiled by independent research firm Markit and sponsored by Caixin, a privately owned Chinese media group.

The PMI data came after US markets tumbled on Thursday to their worst loss of the year over fears for the slowing Chinese economy. "It's all about China; fears are really starting to increase almost like a forest fire," said Daniel Ives, of FBR Capital Markets in the US.

ANGUS GRIGG AND JOHN KEHOE

urn:contentItem:5T1W-FSC1-JD34-V0RR-00000-00Worst fire weather in years2018-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Worst fire weather in yearsAndrew Pearson

Dry winds gusting up to 110km/h and unseasonably-warm winter temperatures combined to deliver the worst August fire weather in more than a decade across parts of the Illawarra and Shoalhaven on Wednesday.

Weatherzone meteorologist Graeme Brittain said the forest fire danger index (FFDI) - which takes into account temperature, wind speed and humidity - reached its highest August level in just over 15 years at Albion Park. Nowra's FFDI was the highest in 14 years.

Wind gusts of 109km/h and 104km/h were recorded at Bellambi and Nowra, respectively, on Wednesday morning. It has been almost two years since Bellambi had a wind gust that strong. The vigorous west to northwesterly winds came ahead of a cold front, which was due to arrive on Wednesday night.

The dangers posed by the strong winds were compounded by temperatures that climbed as high as eight degrees above average for this time of the year.

A maximum of 25.6 degrees was recorded at Bellambi, it was 24.5 in Albion Park and 23.5 at Nowra.

A fire weather warning was issued for the Illawarra/Shoalhaven, Greater Sydney and Greater Hunter fire districts late-morning. Total fire bans were also issued in those areas - the earliest bans of the season in almost a decade, according to the NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS).

The Bureau of Meteorology's NSW severe weather manager Simon Louis said the strong winds and dry conditions combined to cause very-high to severe fire danger across the Illawarra.

The lack of recent rainfall and "very dry fuels" also contributed to the severe fire danger conditions, Mr Louis said. "We haven't had a fire weather warning for the Illawarra in August since 2009, and that again comes back to the very dry lead-in we've had to this season and the very dry state that the fuels are in," he said.

While major fires burned in the Nowra and Ulladulla areas, fallen power lines did spark a blaze off Mount Brandon Road at Jerrara, west of Kiama, just before 9am.

RFS and Fire and Rescue NSW crews worked quickly to protect properties as gusty winds fanned the flames.

RFS district officer David Hitchens described the wind as "quite severe". "Winds that are above 100km/h ... from multiple directions [makes it] very hard to contain a fire and the crews that were here today [Wednesday] did an extremely good job to do that," Mr Hitchens said.

Meanwhile, the wild winds saw NSW State Emergency Service (SES) crews respond to about 65 jobs across the Illawarra and South Coast on Wednesday. More than 30 of the jobs, most of which were for roof damage and fallen trees and branches, were in the Illawarra. The remainder stretched across the Shoalhaven, as far south as Milton.

urn:contentItem:5XGD-SD11-F0J6-J1WG-00000-00Climate change link to fires 'old hat' to scientists2019-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Climate change link to fires 'old hat' to scientistsPeter Hannam Environment editor

EXPLAINERThe evidence is clear to researchers as the fire season continues to grow longer.

As Sydney braces for its first ever day of catastrophic fire danger, it's worth recapping what scientists think about the links between bushfires and a warming world.

Is there a link between climate change and more severe and frequent bushfires?

Measuring danger

The likelihood of hostile extreme weather can be measured in a range of ways. For bushfires, scientists look at the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index, developed in the 1960s by CSIRO scientist A.G. McArthur to forecast how weather would affect fire behaviour.

As the name suggests, the gauge examines the risks to woodlands from fire using a combination of rainfall or drought conditions along with predicted wind speeds, temperature and humidity.

Typically, winter and spring see the highest ratings on this fire danger index in the north and these move southward as spring makes way for summer.

Define catastrophic

Fire and emergency authorities started to review response plans in 2008 to adapt to "growing intensity and severity of recent bushfire experiences across the country".

Then Black Saturday's bushfires erupted in Victoria on February 7, 2009, leaving 173 people dead. That event "brought into sharp focus the possibility that the current legislation, systems, practices and processes to support effective community safety outcomes may no longer match the increasing levels of risk and expectations", a bushfire warning taskforce report noted.

The highest fire danger rating was set as "catastrophic" for index readings of 100 or more - In Victoria, they are dubbed Code Red. The basic message was boiled down to: "For your survival, leaving is the best option."

The dire assessment is because some fires on such days are likely to become "uncontrollable, unpredictable and fast moving" and "there is a very high likelihood that people in the path of the fire will die or be injured", the taskforce said.

Melbourne reached an index reading of about 150 on Black Saturday, according to Ross Bradstock, director of the Centre for Environmental Risk Management of Bushfires at the University of Wollongong.

For Sydney to exceed 100 on the index could be a first, at least for the Observatory Hill and Sydney Airport sites, where the weather is measured.

Climate change role

Yes, there is a link between climate change and the prevalence and severity of fires. In fact, the research is "old hat", says Professor Bradstock. "The research has all been done. We don't need to keep doing it."

As the Bureau of Meteorology and CSIRO pointed out in last year's latest State of the Climate report, the number of the most extreme 10 per cent of fire weather days based on the fire danger index "has increased in recent decades across many regions of Australia, especially in southern and eastern Australia".

"There has been an associated increase in the length of the fire weather season," it said. "Climate change, including increasing temperatures, is contributing to these changes."

In general, one consequence for fire authorities is that the fire season is getting longer. In eastern Australia, that means fire risks start to increase earlier in the spring and last longer into the autumn. The window for hazard-reduction burning is shifting into winter - if it's not too damp to do it.

Is this unusual?

Depending on where you are, very unusual. NSW, for instance, could see a million hectares burned so far this fire season within days - if it hasn't already done so. That is about the same as the past three fire seasons combined - and summer is yet to arrive.

Rainfall deficiencies - or what most of us call "drought" - are already the worst on record for northern NSW and parts of southern Queensland.

And it has also been hot. Of particular concern is predicted heat for the very dry areas around big population centres such as Sydney, Newcastle and Wollongong.

Temperatures are likely to reach the mid to high 30s today at a time when moisture levels in plants - a gauge of how quickly they will burn if fire breaks out - are tracking below those of the big fire season of 2013 in the Sydney area, and the worst since 2002.

Professor Bradstock published research in 2009 predicting the fire danger index would track to 2030 and 2050, using CSIRO data from 2007. "The current predictions [for Sydney on November 12] are beyond what we predicted back in 2007," he says. "That's not good."

urn:contentItem:5RRY-HB01-JD34-V49V-00000-00Grass fire north of Ararat halted in 'good save' | Photos2018-02-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisGrass fire north of Ararat halted in 'good save' | PhotosRex Martinich

A grass fire north of Ararat on Saturday night was brought under control quickly in what the Country Fire Authority described as a 'good save'.

CFA, the State Emergency Service and Forest Fire Management Victoria deployed 38 vehicles and three aircraft to fight the blaze that started at 5pm around Saw Pit Road.

CFA District 16 operations manager Bernie Fradd said he fire would still be going this week if it had reached hilly bushland areas.

"It was just a really good save," he said.

"It had the potential to get into the Regional Park and if it had, in any significant way, the fire would still be going and would be very difficult to put out.

"There was some great work done by the brigades in pulling it up when they did."

He said the CFA had not received any reports about houses or sheds being destroyed in the fire, but the CFA had saved one house while the fire was at its worst on Saturday night.

The CFA issued a 'Watch and Act' message, its second highest alert after 'Advice', for the 60-hectare fire burning 2.8 kilometres north of Ararat just after 6.30pm.

People in the Bulgana and Crowlands areas were advised to activate their fire plan and were warned against fleeing their homes and properties as the fire moved in a north-westerly direction.

"Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly," the VicEmergency website stated at the time.

"Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

The fire was downgraded to the 'advice' level at 7.18pm and the fire was under control by 8pm.

Mr Fradd said just about every brigade from within 20 kilometres of Ararat responded to the fire.

CFA volunteers were still on the scene on Monday and will be there for the next few days due to the number of trees that were still smoldering.

Residents in the affected area thanked CFA volunteers and emergency services but complained that people had blocked roads and ignored closure signs to get a better look at the fire.

Mr Fradd said is was "really dangerous" for spectators to enter a fire zone.

"It makes it harder for firefighters to concentrate on putting out the fire when there are people in cars using the same roads. It's certainly not helpful," he said.

urn:contentItem:5NXY-MWB1-JD34-V50B-00000-00To burn or not to burn?2017-07-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATETo burn or not to burn?

Local fire management crews did more slashing and mowing than planned burns over the past year, departmental figures reveal, but it is not indicative of things to come.

Debate has long raged over the effectiveness, and in some cases safety, of planned burns following an out-of-control Lancefield burn that destroyed four homes in 2015.

Since the fire, the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning has moved from hectare to risk-based planned burn targets.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Assistant Chief Fire Officer, Scott Falconer, said of the 7308 hectares treated in the Loddon Mallee region from July 2016 - June 2017, 3,759 hectares were mechanical.

"Every opportunity is taken to conduct planned burns when the weather is suitable. A decision to burn will only be approved if the area is dry enough to burn at an intensity appropriate to the environment and if the weather is expected to stay calm and mild for at least a few days," he said.

"The conditions leading up to the burn season in the Loddon Mallee region were not ideal. The Murray Goldfields District had a very dry, late summer followed by large amounts of rain in autumn. This meant that many areas were simply too wet to burn."

FFMVic crews had to become more strategic in their plans, for example conducting a 77-hectare burn in Eaglehawk, near Bracewell Street, where the Black Saturday fires had run through in 2009.

The topography of some areas in the Loddon Mallee region made mechanical works more practical, Mr Falconer said.

Across Victoria, during the same period, FFMVic crews conducted 351 burns over 113,172 ha statewide.

A cross bench inquiry into fire season preparedness released a report recently, which recommended that in conjunction with a risk-based approach, a minimum hectare fuel-reduction target is maintained that can be measured and compared.

The report goes onto state the minimum target should not be below the 5 per cent established by the Victorian Bushfire Royal Commission in 2009.

urn:contentItem:5HHT-YH41-JD3N-52V2-00000-00Research into woodheating harm2015-12-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 16Research into woodheating harmBRUCE MOUNSTER

THE University of Tasmania is funding research aimed at reducing the harm caused by smoke given off by woodheaters and fuel reduction burns.

John Todd of the School of Geography and Environ-mental Studies is overseeing the installation of chambers in a Sandy Bay Campus building for analysing smoke from wood heaters and simulated forest and peat burns.

Dr Todd said the new $150,000 -Pyrotron laboratory could also be used to assess the feasibility of gathering leaves, twigs and branches from forest floors and processing them into wood fire pellets.

He said pellets would be the key to the retention of wood heaters as sources of cheap, low CO2 energy, without harmful emissions. He said clean pellet fired heaters were already heating homes in -Europe and North America and used in light industrial -applications including greenhouses and swimming pool heating.

"But the pellet industry here is so small, that they are exp-ensive, and it hasn't taken off." Dr Todd said that if feasible, the removal of the forest litter - the excess fuel that -increased forest fire hazards - from forest floors near cities and towns and its conversion into wood fire pellets would be a perfect solution.

He said the lab could be of service to industries interested in using biomass for large heating and power projects.Pyrotron researchers will contribute to the development of national standards for wood-pellet burning heaters.

CFA volunteers were still on the scene on Monday and will be there for the next few days due to the number of trees that were still smoldering.

Residents in the affected area thanked CFA volunteers and emergency services but complained that people had blocked roads and ignored closure signs to get a better look at the fire.

Mr Fradd said is was "really dangerous" for spectators to enter a fire zone.

"It makes it harder for firefighters to concentrate on putting out the fire when there are people in cars using the same roads. It's certainly not helpful," he said.

urn:contentItem:5RRY-HB01-JD34-V48F-00000-00Grass fire2018-02-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Grass fireRex Martinich

A grass fire north of Ararat on Saturday night was brought under control quickly in what the Country Fire Authority described as a "good save".

CFA, the State Emergency Service and Forest Fire Management Victoria deployed 38 vehicles and three aircraft to fight the blaze that started at 5pm around Saw Pit Road.

CFA District 16 operations manager Bernie Fradd said the fire would still be going this week if it had reached hilly bushland areas.

"It was just a really good save," he said.

"It had the potential to get into the Regional Park and if it had, in any significant way, the fire would still be going and would be very difficult to put out.

"There was some great work done by the brigades in pulling it up when they did."

He said the CFA had not received any reports about houses or sheds being destroyed in the fire, but the CFA had saved one house while the fire was at its worst on Saturday night.

The CFA issued a 'Watch and Act' message, its second highest alert after 'Advice', for the 60-hectare fire burning 2.8 kilometres north of Ararat just after 6.30pm.

People in the Bulgana and Crowlands areas were advised to activate their fire plan and were warned against fleeing their homes and properties as the fire moved in a north-westerly direction.

"Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly," the VicEmergency website stated at the time.

"Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

The fire was downgraded to the "advice" level at 7.18pm and the fire was under control by 8pm.

Mr Fradd said just about every brigade from within 20 kilometres of Ararat responded to the fire.

CFA volunteers were still on the scene on Monday and will be there for the next few days due to the number of trees that were still smoldering.

Residents in the affected area thanked CFA volunteers and emergency services but complained that people had blocked roads and ignored closure signs to get a better look at the fire.

Mr Fradd said is was "really dangerous" for spectators to enter a fire zone.

"It makes it harder for firefighters to concentrate on putting out the fire when there are people in cars using the same roads. It's certainly not helpful," he said.

urn:contentItem:5W25-RWS1-JD34-V371-00000-00Recent rains mean fire season finally has an end in sight2019-05-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisRecent rains mean fire season finally has an end in sightGreg Gliddon

THE extended fire season is finally coming to an end with the CFA confirming fire danger period restrictions will end on May 13.

But the short autumn has raised some concerns that not enough forest burning has been completed, which could cause some issues when the next fire season comes around.

At the weekend there was a series of burns that the CFA was called out to. On Sunday alone, the CFA attended fires at Smythes Creek, Ross Creek and Bung Bong to name just a few.

Duty Officer Gavin Hope said while full-time farmers were generally aware of when restrictions apply, there were concerns with some hobby farmers.

"Sometimes you see smoke in the air and think it must be okay to start burning off, so we do sometimes see issues," he said.

"At this time of the year, a lot of the fires are probably branches and twigs. If you drive around, you will see piles getting ready to burn.

"We do occasionally have people try and tell us that restrictions are off, but there's plenty of signage around and all you have to do is check media reports and they are there."

Mr Hope said it had been an incredibly busy season, which had seen constant big fires.

"There's been quite a few decent jobs in the Ballarat district," he said. "At the start we had Buninyong, then we had Scarsdale, Hepburn, Haddon and Bunkers Hill and Mount Clear.

"Plus obviously we've had plenty of cars and house fires, and many car accident rescues.

"Hopefully now the bushfires will die off in someway, but obviously as it cools down we now get more house fires, people drying clothes, things like that and slippery roads can lead to more accidents."

Forest Fire Management Midlands District Manager Jasmine Filmer said this year's season had problematic in that there hadn't been the string of still, warm days needed to complete every planned burn.

"We've had a couple of burns around Ballarat, we've also done some burning in the Wombat State Forest, Trentham Racecourse Road, Blackwood, Albion track.

"This time last year we had finished, but the forecast rainfall this week has probably put an end to burns int he Wombat, but we still hope to get in some burns around Beaufort and in Anakie.

"For (planned burns) around Smythesdale and Linton we are going to need some good drying days in the next few weeks, but this week does look unfavourable."

Ms Filmer said agencies would get together this week to plan for the next few years.

She said said it was hard to predict whether some burns could be completed in spring as weather was not as usually settled as the autumn months.

Mr Hope said even when the fire danger period comes off, people wishing to burn should still heed fire safety practices.

"Don't leave fires unattended, make sure you keep an eye on them and make sure they are fully out," he said.

"There is still dry soil, so it's important to keep an eye on the wind conditions, you never know when something can spring up."

He said while fires would generally be out in country areas, he warned there could be a lot more smoke around once restrictions were off, with people suffering breathing difficulties to be aware of the possibly of poor air quality.

urn:contentItem:5NWB-WCR1-JD3N-51NW-00000-00Double standards2017-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Double standardsANTHONY GALLOWAY

MORE than 1000 firefighters who work for the environment department could be given cancer compensation before those at the CFA and MFB.

The Andrews Government is set to introduce a Bill giving presumptive rights to -forest firefighters working for the -Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Parks Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

This is despite the government insisting compensation for CFA and MFB firefighters only becomes law as part of its controversial Bill to restructure the state's fire services.

Presumptive rights mean firefighters suffering certain cancers do not have to prove their illness was related to work to receive compensation.

It is understood the Opposition, while opposing the -restructure, would support a separate Bill to deliver -presumptive rights for all -firefighters.

Opposition emergency services spokesman Brad Battin said there should be one Bill for presumptive rights and a separate Bill for the restructure.

"All firefighters deserve cancer protection," Mr Battin said. "Daniel Andrews' cruel decision to force CFA and MFB firefighters to support tearing apart the CFA in exchange for their protection shows this Premier is more about politics than protecting them." It is understood the DELWP is developing the separate Bill for its forest firefighters.

The restructure Bill has been sent to a parliamentary committee for further scrutiny and doesn't yet have the support of crossbench MPs to pass the upper house.

Before it was sent to the committee, the government was planning to pass the restructure Bill last week, then introduce the proposed laws for forest firefighters in August.

Asked whether forest firefighters could receive presumptive rights before the CFA and MFB's firefighters, Environment Minister Lily D'Ambrosio said: "The government will introduce legislation in the second half of this year." Under the government's plan to restructure the fire services, the MFB would be abolished and all paid firefighters moved to a new service called Fire Rescue Victoria. The new agency would also take over all of the CFA's 35 integrated fire stations, taking from it all of its paid firefighters.anthony.galloway@news.com.au

urn:contentItem:5XGF-DF81-F0JP-W3VF-00000-00Herald Sun2019-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisOPEDPg. 22Herald Sun

State braces for fire test LAST fire season, more than 4500 fires broke out across Victoria. The reality is more bushfires will erupt this summer - be it through lightning, power line failure, negligence or criminal idiocy.

Off the back of three years of record-low rainfall, the risk of a treacherous season is racing closer, and there is absolutely no room for complacency or failure to properly prepare.

The horror fires sweeping large parts of Queensland and New South Wales at present are a salient reminder of just how dire things can quickly get.

According to the Australian Seasonal Bushfire Outlook, Victoria's Forest Fire Danger Index (FFDI) - based on temperatures and average rainfall - has increased by 50 per cent since 1950, with 2018-19 the fourth highest warning level on record. The outlook, developed by the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre and the Bureau of Meteorology, also warns of "severe levels of underlying dryness persisting in soils and heavy forest fuels, along with higher abundance of dead fuel components and higher flammability of live vegetation".

For the first time ever, greater Sydney was yesterday classified as facing "catastrophic" danger and fire risks are today forecast to elevate again across northern states.

Victoria has deployed 370 firefighters and specialists to NSW and another 36 to Queensland to assist with the current fires that have killed three people and destroyed more than 150 properties.

In Victoria, a total fire ban was declared for the Mallee yesterday and fire restrictions have been imposed in parts of Gippsland.

Above-normal bushfire conditions have been designated from the coast and hinterland forests of East Gippsland, extending into West Gippsland and the Great Dividing Range.

Emergency authorities have also warned of high risk that ash forests in the Central Highlands and Otways may dry out at faster rates than expected in coming weeks and months.

While winter rains have been effective in some parts of western Victoria, the east and northeast regions will be hot spots for fire.

Emergency Management Victoria has an increased fleet of 50 helicopters and fixed-wing aircraft, including a mix of water bombing, supervision and air intelligence assets at its disposal, with access to a further 100 in emergency situations. Two air tankers can each carry up to 15,000 litres of water, foam or retardant and two air cranes, capable of carrying 7500 litres of water will be strategically positioned across the state. To illustrate the elevated threat levels of recent years, firefighting aircraft were deployed 2455 times last fire season in Victoria - an increase of 11 per cent on the previous year. But, while air support has been bolstered, the government's politicisation of the fire services has eroded surge capacity within the Country Fire Authority.

While the CFA's chief officer Steve Warrington argued capacity remains stable, the agency's annual report said more than 1000 volunteers had left the service in the past year. In September, the Herald Sun revealed the CFA had again missed its targets, with 34,380 volunteers, the fewest since 2006. With the high chances of Victoria's rural fire services facing significant tests this summer, it is vital volunteer surge capacity be addressed and protected.

Tech response to abuse FOR decades, the wider community and authorities lacked focus on the issue of domestic violence and protecting victims.

In suburban homes, behind closed doors, partners and children have been subject to hidden violence and abuse. Sometimes, the result has been tragically lethal. Often, the result has been damaging long-term.

Thankfully, greater attention is now being imposed, following the Royal Commission into Family Violence and education initiatives, including the Herald Sun's Take a Stand campaign.

But making real inroads into reporting and responding to family violence, identifying risks, ensuring victims and children are given absolute priority in safety, and adopting preventive measures, are all areas for further work.

Change has begun, including the bolstering of Victoria Police's specialist services and dedicated lawyers within the criminal justice system to respond to DV cases.

The digital frontier is the latest aspect to receive attention, and reform is needed when it comes to stalking and online intrusion.

As reported in today's newspaper, police are looking at options to generate early-warning identifiers and better respond to online harassment. Assistant Commissioner Dean McWhirter said it was critical for police to "keep ahead of the game" when it came to new apps and technologies that can be used to continue abuse or stalk. One option to be assessed is a Tasmanian trial of GPS trackers for domestic abusers.If the starting and end point is protection, whatever technologies that can be deployed, should be.

urn:contentItem:5MTY-9SB1-JD34-V2WC-00000-00The Eyre Peninsula was feeling...2017-02-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8The Eyre Peninsula was feeling...

The Eyre Peninsula was feeling the warm conditions on Wednesday, which coincided with a report warning Australians to expect more extreme weather events as climate change worsens.

Temperatures rose across South Australia on Wednesday with the Bureau of Meteorology forecasting a maximum of 38 degrees for Port Lincoln.

This is around the mark for Port Lincoln's highest temperature for 2016 which was 38.5 on December 26 and higher than the maximum for February last year, which was 32.7 on February 23.

The temperature is expected to remain in the 30s today with a forecast of 32 degrees.

Cummins reached 42 at about 12.30pm with 18 per cent humidity while Tumby Bay was cooler reaching about 30 at noon with 64 per cent humidity.

According to the Climate Council of Australia report released yesterday, Cranking Up the Intensity: Climate Change and Extreme Weather Events, Australia is experiencing hotter and longer heatwaves with increased bushfire risk as fire seasons are lasting longer.

It said the Forest Fire Danger Index may increase across southern Australia, including coastal regions by seven per cent by 2030 and by 30 per cent by 2090 under a high emissions scenario.

As well as hot conditions the report has linked climate change to extreme storm events, including the storm that affected South Australia in September last year, which took out power across the state, including Port Lincoln.

It states the oceans are warming, especially at the surface, which is driving higher evaporation rates and the warmer atmosphere can hold more water vapour.

The report said the one per cent increase in global temperatures, together with increasing evaporation had lead to a seven per cent increase in water vapour in the atmosphere.

The report said the burning of fossil fuels was linked to the temperature rises with Australia set to miss its target of a 26 to 28 per cent reduction in emissions by the year 2030.

urn:contentItem:5NTW-36N1-JD3N-50DR-00000-00Portugal's pain as 62 die in massive forest inferno2017-06-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 22Portugal's pain as 62 die in massive forest infernoHELENA ALVES PEDROGAO GRANDE

A RAGING forest fire in central Portugal has killed at least 62 people as they desperately tried to flee, charring cars and trucks as it swept over roads.

The disaster - the worst tragedy Portugal has experienced in decades - shook the nation, with the president declaring that the country's pain "knows no end".

Almost 24 hours after the deaths on Saturday night, fires were still churning across the forested hillsides of central Portugal yesterday.

Police and firefighters were searching charred areas of the forest and isolated homes, looking for more bodies.

"It is a time of pain but also ... a time to carry on the fight" against the flames, President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa told the nation in a televised address yesterday after the government declared three days of national mourning.

A huge wall of thick smoke and bright red flames towered over the tops of trees in the forested Pedrogao Grande area, 150km northeast of Lisbon.

At least four other significant wildfires were burning yesterday elsewhere in Portugal but the one in Pedrogao Grande was responsible for all the deaths.

"The dimensions of this fire have caused a human tragedy beyond any in our memory," Prime Minister Antonio Costa said as he arrived at the scene yesterday. "Something extraordinary has taken place and we have to wait for experts to properly determine its causes." A lightning strike is believed to have sparked the blaze in the Pedrogao Grande area after investigators found a tree that was hit during a "dry thunderstorm," the head of the national judicial police said. â€ƒDry thunderstorms are frequent when falling water evaporates before reaching the ground because of high temperatures.

Portugal is prone to forest fires in the dry summer months. "This is a region that has had fires ... but we cannot remember a tragedy of these proportions," said Valdemar Alves, mayor of Pedrogao Grande. "I am completely stunned by the number of deaths." Minister Constanca Urbano de Sousa said the death toll had risen to 62 by yesterday.She said police were expecting to complete the identification of the bodies as soon as possible. -AP

urn:contentItem:5NVM-KB81-JCM0-64D1-00000-00Wedge-tailed eagles deliberately killed in north-east Victoria2017-06-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisWedge-tailed eagles deliberately killed in north-east VictoriaBy Erin Somerville

Wildlife authorities have raised concerns about an increase in fatal attacks on native wedge-tailed eagles in north-east Victoria.

The carcasses of four eagles have been discovered in the Black Range State Forest, near Yea, by Forest Fire Management Victoria crews conducting a routine patrol.

All four eagles had been shot.

The latest discovery brings the total of wedge-tailed eagles that have been found shot or poisoned in the same area during recent years to 20.

Last year alone the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) located eight eagles that had been killed by poison within a 25-metre radius of each other near the Yea area.

DELWP's spokesman, Darren Skelton, said authorities were very concerned about the deliberate and cruel attacks on native wildlife.

"It's concerning for the community to know that there are people out there who are intentionally killing these wonderful birds," he said.

Wedge-tailed eagles are Australia's largest bird of prey.

Mr Skelton said the eagles could sometimes be targeted by farmers who fear for the safety of newborn lambs, but he said eagles were only a minimal threat to young livestock.

"What we know is that wedge-tailed eagles are far more likely to get a feed off road kill or other species than they are off lambs," he said.

Wedge-tailed eagles are protected under the Wildlife Act 1975 and deliberately hunting or killing the birds carries a penalty of around $8,000, or up to six months' imprisonment.

"We know most people admire and value eagles and the role they play in the local environment as well as contributing to our state's biodiversity, " DELWP senior wildlife officer, Leigh Murray, said.

"This type of activity is definitely not acceptable."

DELWP is calling on the community to help gather information about the eagles' deaths in an attempt to prosecute the offenders.

Information can be provided anonymously by phoning DELWP's Customer Service Centre on 136 186 or Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

urn:contentItem:5V2F-CR21-JD34-V1J2-00000-00Robbie Miller upbeat as he recovers from Laharum fire injuries2018-12-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSRobbie Miller upbeat as he recovers from Laharum fire injuriesRichard Crabtree Carly Werner

LAHARUM'S Robbie Miller is determined to stay positive after being burned while helping fight a harvest fire on Christmas Eve.

The Laharum Football Netball Club senior football coach was among dozens of firefighters and community members who responded when harvest operations sparked a blaze at Laharum on Monday afternoon.

Country Fire Authority crews, private units and Forest Fire Management Victoria personnel used tankers, fire-bombing aircraft and other machinery to control the fire.

Mr Miller was on the back of a water cart when a gust of wind pushed flames in his direction, trapping him.

He was rushed to Melbourne's The Alfred hospital with arm and leg injuries. Mr Miller said an operation on Christmas night went well, and he remains in the hospital's burns unit recovering.

"They're just trying to figure out a plan because my wife is 39 weeks pregnant. We're trying to figure out if I can get to Horsham and get closer to see her if she does happen to go into labour," he said.

"I couldn't believe it. A truck started the fire and we had no idea how that happened. I was on the back of the water cart and this massive gust of wind came along and the flames got pretty intense and we couldn't get away from it.

"I was stuck there trying to protect myself with the hose and that didn't really do too much."

Mr Miller said he was holding up alright given the circumstances.

"It's probably one of the toughest things I've ever had to experience," he said.

"I've had a bit of bad luck and bad injuries with football, but to be burnt is a completely different pain and rehab process. It's not something I would ever want anyone to experience.

"Because I haven't had to have skin grafts, the (recovery) time frame is probably going to be a bit longer. I have to wait until the burns heal and then I'll see what work and physical activity I can do from there."

Mr Miller has had a horror year with injury, breaking his leg twice during the football season.

But he remains upbeat.

"I've had a pretty horrid run the last 12 months or so but it is what it is and I've got light at the end of the tunnel," he said.

"What keeps me upbeat is there are a lot more people unfortunately worse off than me. You just have to sit in your room for 10 minutes and you see the other burn victims walk past and it's pretty bloody bad.

"You hear all these stories. Especially the nurses say there's a lot of burn victims that come through because of barbecues and stuff like that, and you hear that on the news but you never expect it to be yourself.

"But stuff happens and you just have to keep on top of the positiveness."

Mr Miller said he had been overwhelmed with messages of support.

"The response from people - people I haven't spoken to in years and people I never thought I'd hear from again - who have sent me get well messages, it's just been amazing," he said.

urn:contentItem:5RJD-DSB1-F0J6-J37W-00000-00Crews set for mercury to climb as heat spikes over weekend2018-01-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Crews set for mercury to climb as heat spikes over weekendStuart McGuckin

WITH temperatures set to soar above 40 degrees at the weekend, Country Fire Authority District 17 operations manager Dale Russell has advised residents to brace for the conditions.

The Bureau of Meteorology's Thursday forecast tipped the mercury to climb to 37 degrees on Friday before maximums of 41 and 43 on Saturday and Sunday.

"My message to the public is to defer doing things on those days - either do it now or defer it to next week," Mr Russell said.

"We don't want people out in the heat from their own health point of view in terms of fatigue and dehydration.

"Then from a fire point of view, we know in hot, dry and windy conditions it doesn't take much to start a fire."

He said the authority received regular advice from the Bureau of Meteorology so it could be as prepared as possible for potentially dangerous conditions.

"Because of the temperatures and weather forecast by the bureau, we will have what we call readiness days on Friday, Saturday and Sunday," he said.

"The bureau usually gives us pretty good notice four or five days out and that is refined every day.

"We start planning as soon as we know we have a spike day, which is when the temperature is up, the wind is up and the humidity is down"

Planning involves the different agencies working together to ensure it is clear what people will be responsible for what tasks.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said there were standard procedures across the state which dictated how agencies prepared.

"We have teams organised to make sure we have firefighters ready to go and also an incident management team in place on the hot days," he said.

"We'll have incident management teams pre-formed regardless of if there are any incidents."

He said the majority of fires happened in the region during January and February.

"We're definitely on alert," he said.

"The heat events are the ones we really watch out for. We've been lucky so far this season that there haven't been to many events but things are really starting to ramp up now."

Mr Russell said it was business as usual for CFA, Department of Land, Environment, Water and Planning and the State Emergency Service.

"That's the Wimmera and that's summer - the reality is that it gets hot and windy up here," he said.

urn:contentItem:5PRD-SPK1-JD34-V05X-00000-00Dozens killed as wildfires rip through Portugal, Spain2017-10-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 19Dozens killed as wildfires rip through Portugal, SpainAndrei Khalip and Raquel Castillo

Nearly 40 people have died in wildfires raging through parched farmlands and forests in Portugal and in neighbouring north-western Spain.

About 4000 firefighters were working to extinguish at least 65 blazes in Portugal yesterday.

Authorities have asked for international help and declared a state of emergency in territory north of the Tagus River - about half the country's land mass.

Flames ripped across Iberian countryside left tinder-dry by an unusually hot summer and early autumn, fanned by strong winds as remnants of ex-Hurricane Ophelia brushed coastal areas.

Television footage showed abandoned villages with many houses in embers and charred vehicles left on the roads.

Portuguese opposition parties and the media harshly criticised the government for failing to prevent a new wave of deadly fires after the country's worst-ever forest fire in June that killed 64 people.

Prime Minister Antonio Costa, however, refused to sack his interior minister and defended his government's attempts to reform the troubled forestry management system.

"It's a structural problem that we are facing. This is not a time for resignations but for solutions," he told reporters after a television address to the nation.

"Everything has to be transformed into reforms, to provide responses that the country needs so that nothing stays the way it was after this year. We are aware that the country wants results from us, and we're running against time after decades of negligence."

At the heart of the problem is poor land management in Portugal, where traditional small plots have become fire hazards after being abandoned by generations of landholders who moved to the cities.

Interior Minister Constanca Urbano de Sousa said climate change was also to blame. "We are facing new [weather] conditions ... In an era of climate change, such disasters are becoming reality all over the world," she said.

Spanish authorities said more than 90 fires were burning in the northern regions of Asturias and Galicia, where authorities confirmed that at least four people had died.

Leader of Galicia Alberto Nunez Feijoo said many of the fires were deliberately lit. "The only thing we desire is that these criminals pay for what they have done," he said.

Two weeks ago, Galicia dismissed 436 forest rangers who had been hired on temporary contracts over the summer months.

urn:contentItem:5PNY-J7X1-F0JP-W4DW-00000-00Killer infernos rage through California2017-10-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 16Killer infernos rage through California

AT least 10 people are dead after more than a dozen wildfires whipped by powerful winds swept through California wine country.

Authorities said the blaze destroyed 1500 homes and businesses, sending thousands fleeing as flames raged unchecked through high-end resorts, grocery stores and tree-lined neighbourhoods.

As he fled through the ember-strewn streets of his neighbourhood in Santa Rosa, Jeff Okrepkie knew it was probably the last time he would see his home of the past five years standing.

His worst fears were confirmed on Monday morning, when a friend sent him a photo of what was left: a smouldering heap of burnt metal and debris.

"We live in the valley, where it's concrete and strip malls and hotels and supermarkets," Mr Okrepkie said. "The last thing you think is a forest fire is going to come and wipe us out." "It was an inferno like you've never seen before," said Marian Williams, who caravanned with neighbours before dawn as one of the wildfires reached the vineyards and ridges at her small Sonoma County town of Kenwood.

Ms Williams could feel the heat of her fire through the car as she fled. "Trees were on fire like torches," she said.

The flames were burning "at explosive rates" because of (80km/h) winds, said Ken Pimlott, director of the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.

Fourteen large fires were burning north of San Francisco, prompting Governor Jerry Brown to declare a state of emergency in Napa, Sonoma and Yuba counties.

It was unusual to have so many fires take off at the same time, fire officials said, although October has generally been the most destructive time of year for California wildfires.

The ferocity of the flames forced authorities to focus primarily on getting people out safely, even if it meant abandoning structures to the fire. The fire area covered more than 160sq km over eight counties.

Some of the largest blazes were in Napa and Sonoma counties, home to dozens of wineries that attract tourists from around the world.

The fires sent smoke as far south as San Francisco, about 96km away. Fires also burned in Yuba, Butte and Nevada counties - all north of the state capital.Police said the fires started about 10pm Sunday.

urn:contentItem:5MS4-S401-F0J6-J0V7-00000-00Crews to suppress bushfire2017-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisCrews to suppress bushfireJeremy Venosta

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews worked for two days to contain a blaze in rocky terrain at the Mount Cole State Park near Warrak on Sunday and Monday.

The fire burnt eight hectares of bush along the Warrak-Branding Yard Track, while firefighters battled to create containment lines in tough conditions.

Incident controller John Rofe said on Monday the fire was likely sparked by a lightning storm during rainfall late last week.

"It is currently contained and we have fire crews working on the fire ground today," he said.

"Their main focus today is finishing construction of containment lines using hand tools."

Mr Rofe said most of the fire zone was inaccessible to vehicles on Monday.

"We have had a bulldozer and firetrucks into a part of the fire, but we have been using ground crews in the steeper rocky part," he said.

"We have also been well supported by two fixed wing aircraft from Stawell, which have been utilised constructing what we call retardant lines.

"There has also been a water bombing helicopter based at Ballarat, which has assisted attacking the hot spots."

Seventy firefighters from the fire management crews and Country Fire Authority responded to the blaze on Sunday.

Another 40 firefighters continued work to contain the fire on Monday.

Vic Emergency advised there was no threat to the Ben Nevis, Elmhurst, Eversley, Warrak, Buangor and Mount Cole communities on Sunday, and residents should continue to monitor the situation.

Mr Rofe said fire crews would continue work to completely black out the blaze on Monday.

"The fire is currently contained and there is no active running fire today," he said.

Ararat Fire Brigade members also completed a burn-off of scrub on the Western Highway between Green Hill Lake Road and Warrayatkin Road on Sunday.

The burn-off was part of an effort to reduce fuel around major townships.

"It was an inferno like you've never seen before," said Marian Williams, who caravanned with neighbours before dawn as one of the wildfires reached the vineyards and ridges at her small Sonoma County town of Kenwood.

Ms Williams could feel the heat of her fire through the car as she fled. "Trees were on fire like torches," she said.

The flames were burning "at explosive rates" because of (80km/h) winds, said Ken Pimlott, director of the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.

Fourteen large fires were burning north of San Francisco, prompting Gov. Jerry Brown to declare a state of emergency in Napa, Sonoma and Yuba counties.

It was unusual to have so many fires take off at the same time, fire officials said, though October has generally been the most destructive time of year for California wildfires.

The ferocity of the flames forced authorities to focus primarily on getting people out safely, even if it meant abandoning structures to the fire. The fire area covered more than 160sq km over eight counties.

Some of the largest blazes were in Napa and Sonoma counties, home to dozens of wineries that attract tourists from around the world.

Those fires sent smoke as far south as San Francisco, about 96km away. Fires also burned in Yuba, Butte and Nevada counties - all north of the state capital. Police said the fires started about 10pm Sunday.

urn:contentItem:5MS4-S401-F0J6-J0W6-00000-00Crews to suppress bushfire2017-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisFRONT PAGEPg. 1Crews to suppress bushfireJeremy Venosta

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews worked for two days to contain a blaze in rocky terrain at the Mount Cole State Park near Warrak on Sunday and Monday.

The fire burnt eight hectares of bush along the Warrak-Branding Yard Track, while firefighters battled to create containment lines in tough conditions.

Incident controller John Rofe said on Monday the fire was likely sparked by a lightning storm during rainfall late last week.

"It is currently contained and we have fire crews working on the fire ground today," he said.

"Their main focus today is finishing construction of containment lines using hand tools."

Mr Rofe said most of the fire zone was inaccessible to vehicles on Monday.

"We have had a bulldozer and firetrucks into a part of the fire, but we have been using ground crews in the steeper rocky part," he said.

"We have also been well supported by two fixed wing aircraft from Stawell, which have been utilised constructing what we call retardant lines.

"There has also been a water bombing helicopter based at Ballarat, which has assisted attacking the hot spots."

Seventy firefighters from the fire management crews and Country Fire Authority responded to the blaze on Sunday.

Another 40 firefighters continued work to contain the fire on Monday.

Vic Emergency advised there was no threat to the Ben Nevis, Elmhurst, Eversley, Warrak, Buangor and Mount Cole communities on Sunday, and residents should continue to monitor the situation.

Mr Rofe said fire crews would continue work to completely black out the blaze on Monday.

"The fire is currently contained and there is no active running fire today," he said.

Ararat Fire Brigade members also completed a burn-off of scrub on the Western Highway between Green Hill Lake Road and Warrayatkin Road on Sunday.

The burn-off was part of an effort to reduce fuel around major townships.

urn:contentItem:5KJ4-H6V1-F0N8-R088-00000-00Indigenous fire workshop2016-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:25ZLexisNexisNEWSIndigenous fire workshop

An Indigenous fire workshop at Wujal Wujal this week will look at the link between fire and climate change and how it impacts the Great Barrier Reef.

Wildfires release many tonnes of carbon into the atmosphere every year as carbon dioxide.

The increased carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is a major contributor to global warming.

The workshop, held annually on Cape York, teaches traditional fire practices which can help reduce excessive carbon release through wildfire.

Cape York NRM's operations manager Peta-Marie Standley said that the relationship between wildfire and climate change was clear.

'Fire and water are connected at both a global and a local scale,' Ms Standley said.

'Traditional Indigenous fire practices involve low intensity fires to manage country, and avoid these large wildfires by reducing wildfire conditions.

'Frequent high intensity fires can also increase bare ground accelerating the potential for erosion.

'Gully erosion has been a major problem on Cape York, and a key contributor to the sedimentation to the Great Barrier Reef off Cape York.

'However low intensity fire leaves fine and coarse woody debris and importantly, the organic matter and ash remain at the site.

'This in turn increases the carbon in the soil and improves soil condition.'

Cape York NRM has been working with CSIRO, the Bureau of Meteorology and James Cook University to plan for the impacts of climate change on Cape York.

'We have undertaken detailed projections for the Forest Fire Danger Index for Cairns, which is comparable to Wujal Wujal,' Ms Standley said.

'The projections show that the current rises in fire conditions for our region are further increased under climate modelling.

'We will present this work at the fire workshop, so that the rainforest communities can plan for climate change.'

The workshop concludes on Friday.

AT least 10 people are dead after more than a dozen wildfires whipped by powerful winds swept through California wine country.

Authorities said the blaze destroyed 1500 homes and businesses, sending thousands fleeing as flames raged unchecked through high-end resorts, grocery stores and tree-lined neighbourhoods.

As he fled through the ember-strewn streets of his neighbourhood in Santa Rosa, Jeff Okrepkie knew it was probably the last time he would see his home of the past five years standing.

His worst fears were confirmed on Monday morning, when a friend sent him a photo of what was left: a smouldering heap of burnt metal and debris.

The ferocity of the flames forced authorities to focus primarily on getting people out safely, even if it meant abandoning structures to the fire. The fire area covered more than 160sq"km over eight counties.
